snippet.title: Circumcised and uncircumcised men enjoy the same amount of sensitivity, study shows - TomoNews

localized.description:
TORONTO — Canadian researchers published a new study that concludes circumcision does not reduce penile sensitivity among adults.

Researchers conducted experiments on 62 healthy men aged from 18 to 37, with 30 of them circumcised and 32 uncircumcised. The tests included tactile and heat sensitivity of the penis at the midline shaft, the area next to the midline, the glans and the foreskin. An area inside of the forearm was tested as a control.

The test results show uncircumcised and circumcised men did not differ in sensitivity at any of the penile sites and sensitivity at the forearm was lower than the other sites for both groups. In fact, the foreskin actually had similar sensitivity as the control site on the forearm.

"This study indicates that neonatal circumcision is not associated with changes in penile sensitivity and provides preliminary evidence to suggest that the foreskin is not the most sensitive part of the penis," lead author Jennifer Bossio, PhD candidate in Clinical Psychology of the Department of Psychology, Queen's University in Ontario told eCanadaNow. 

The study also shows that sexual functioning may not differ across the circumcision status.
